member.name: T:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.BigRegister
member.summary: BigRegister holds a multiprecision unsigned integer value. It is mutable and supports common arithmetic operations. Be careful NOT to simply assign one BigRegister to another, unless you really know what you are doing. The proper way to replicate a BigRegister is via the constructor "BigRegister(ref BigRegister reg)", or with reg1.Load(ref reg2). Using the ctor marks the buffer as shared so changing the value of one register will not affect the other. Using Load copies the contents from one to the other. Either way, the internal buffer isn't aliased incorrectly.

member.name: T:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.ILinearModel
member.summary: An ILinearModel instance encapsulates a linear optimization problem consisting of decision variables, constraints, and goals. The LinearModel class implements ILinearModel and the SimplexSolver class derives from LinearModel.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.ILinearModel.IsQuadraticVariable(System.Int32)
member.summary: Does the variable participate in any quadratic row

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.ILinearModel.AddRow(System.Object,System.Int32@)
member.summary: If the model already includes a row referenced by key, this sets vid to the rows index and returns false. Otherwise, if the model already includes a user variable referenced by key, this sets vid to -1 and returns false. Otherwise, this adds a new row associated with key to the model, assigns the next available index to the new row, sets vid to this index, and returns true.
member.returns: true if added successfully, otherwise false

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.ILinearModel.AddRow(System.Object,Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.SpecialOrderedSetType,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Add a reference row for a SOS set. Each SOS set has one reference row
member.param: the vid of the reference row

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.ILinearModel.AddVariable(System.Object,System.Int32@)
member.summary: The AddVariable method ensures that a user variable with the given key is in the model. If the model already includes a user variable referenced by key, this sets vid to the variables index and returns false. Otherwise, if the model already includes a row referenced by key, this sets vid to -1 and returns false. Otherwise, this adds a new user variable associated with key to the model, assigns the next available index to the new variable, sets vid to this index, and returns true.
member.returns: true if added successfully, otherwise false

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.ILinearModel.IsRow(System.Int32)
member.summary: validate if it is a row index
member.returns: true if a row otherwise false

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.ILinearModel.TryGetIndexFromKey(System.Object,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Try to get the variable index based on the key
member.returns: true if the variable exists, otherwise false

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.ILinearModel.GetIndexFromKey(System.Object)
member.summary: Maps the variable index from the key. If not found, KeyNotFoundException will be thrown
member.returns: variable index

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.ILinearModel.GetKeyFromIndex(System.Int32)
member.summary: Map from the variable index to the key. If not found, ArgumentException will be thrown
member.returns: the variable key
member.remarks: key might be null

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.ILinearModel.SetBounds(System.Int32,Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.Rational,Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.Rational)
member.summary: Logically, a vid may have an upper bound of Infinity and/or a lower bound of -Infinity. Specifying any other non-finite values for bounds should be avoided. If a vid has a lower bound that is greater than its upper bound, the model is automatically infeasible, now the ArgumentException is thrown for this case.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.ILinearModel.SetLowerBound(System.Int32,Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.Rational)
member.summary: set or adjust the lower bound of the variable

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.ILinearModel.SetUpperBound(System.Int32,Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.Rational)
member.summary: set or adjust the upper bound of the variable

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.ILinearModel.GetBounds(System.Int32,Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.Rational@,Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.Rational@)
member.summary: Return the bounds for the variable

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.ILinearModel.SetValue(System.Int32,Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.Rational)
member.summary: The default value for a vid is Indeterminate. An ILinearModel can be used to represent not just a linear model, but also a current state for the models (user and row) variables. The state associates with each vid a current value, represented as a Rational, and a basis status, represented as a boolean. This state may be used as a starting point when solving, and may be updated by a solve attempt. In particular, invoking the Solve method of the SimplexSolver class updates the values and basis status appropriately. Some other solvers may ignore this initial state for rows and even for variables.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.ILinearModel.GetValue(System.Int32)
member.summary: Get the value associated with the variable index. This is typically used to fetch solver result
member.returns: the variable value

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.ILinearModel.GetValueState(System.Int32)
member.summary: Get the value state of this variable
member.returns: variable state

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.ILinearModel.SetIgnoreBounds(System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Adjusts whether the bounds of a vid should be respected or ignored during solving. By default, bounds are respected.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.ILinearModel.GetIgnoreBounds(System.Int32)
member.summary: Get the flag whether is bound is ignored
member.returns: true if bounds are ignored, otherwise false

member.summary: The SetBasic method sets the basis status for a variable. The default basis status for a variable is false. The SimplexSolver class updates these flags after a solve attempt.
member.param: whether set it to a basic variable

member.returns: true if this variable is a basic variable. otherwise false

member.name: T:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.ILinearSolution
member.summary: An ILinearSolution instance encapsulates the result of attempting to solve an ILinearModel. It contains the following information: . The solvers final status, retrievable from the SolutionQuality, Result, LpResult, and MipResult properties. . The variable values, indicating the solvers best attempt at an optimal feasible solution. The GetValue method provides this information. . Information on which variables are basic and which bounds are binding, non-binding or violated. The GetBasic and GetValueState methods provide this information. . Detailed information on which goals were considered and solved to optimality.

member.summary: The InnerSlackCount property returns the number of row variables used internally when solving the linear model. This may be less than the ILinearModel.RowCount, since row variables may be eliminated by presolve.

member.name: P:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.ILinearSimplexStatistics.InnerRowCount
member.summary: The InnerRowCount property returns the number of rows used internally when solving the linear model. This may be less than ILinearModel.RowCount since rows may be eliminated by presolve.

member.name: T:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.SimplexDirective
member.summary: Directive for the simplex solver.
member.remarks: The simplex solver is suitable for linear models with real decisions. In the case of a model with no goals, the simplex solver will report an Optimal solution. By contrast the constraint programming solver reports Feasible.

member.name: P:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.Directive.MaximumGoalCount
member.summary: Maximum number of goals to use, if multiple goals are supported. Disabled goals are considered in this count. For example, if you have 3 goals, which from them the second is disabled. Setting the MaximumGoalCount to 2 will make the first goal the only goal to be considered.

member.name: T:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.IRowVariableModel
member.summary: IRowVariableModel represents optimization models consisting of decision variables and rows.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.IRowVariableModel.GetIndexFromKey(System.Object)
member.summary: Maps the variable index from the key. If not found, KeyNotFoundException will be thrown
member.returns: variable index

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.IRowVariableModel.TryGetIndexFromKey(System.Object,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Try to get the variable index based on the key
member.returns: true if the variable exists, otherwise false

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.IRowVariableModel.GetKeyFromIndex(System.Int32)
member.summary: Map from the variable index to the key. If not found, ArgumentException will be thrown
member.returns: the variable key
member.remarks: key might be null

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.IRowVariableModel.AddRow(System.Object,System.Int32@)
member.summary: If the model already includes a row referenced by key, this sets vid to the rows index and returns false. Otherwise, if the model already includes a user variable referenced by key, this sets vid to -1 and returns false. Otherwise, this adds a new row associated with key to the model, assigns the next available index to the new row, sets vid to this index, and returns true.
member.returns: true if added successfully, otherwise false

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.IRowVariableModel.IsRow(System.Int32)
member.summary: Validate if it is a row index and not a variable index.
member.returns: True if a row otherwise false.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.IRowVariableModel.SetIgnoreBounds(System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Adjusts whether the bounds of a vid should be respected or ignored during solving. By default, bounds are respected.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.IRowVariableModel.GetIgnoreBounds(System.Int32)
member.summary: Get the flag whether is bound is ignored.
member.returns: true if bounds are ignored, otherwise false

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.IRowVariableModel.SetBounds(System.Int32,Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.Rational,Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.Rational)
member.summary: Set the bounds for a vid.
member.remarks: Logically, a vid may have an upper bound of Infinity and/or a lower bound of -Infinity. Specifying any other non-finite values for bounds should be avoided. If a vid has a lower bound that is greater than its upper bound, the model is automatically infeasible, and ArgumentException is thrown.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.IRowVariableModel.SetLowerBound(System.Int32,Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.Rational)
member.summary: Set or adjust the lower bound of the vid.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.IRowVariableModel.SetUpperBound(System.Int32,Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.Rational)
member.summary: Set or adjust the upper bound of the vid.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.IRowVariableModel.GetBounds(System.Int32,Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.Rational@,Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.Rational@)
member.summary: Return the bounds for the vid.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.IRowVariableModel.AddVariable(System.Object,System.Int32@)
member.summary: The AddVariable method ensures that a user variable with the given key is in the model. If the model already includes a user variable referenced by key, this sets vid to the variables index and returns false. Otherwise, if the model already includes a row referenced by key, this sets vid to -1 and returns false. Otherwise, this adds a new user variable associated with key to the model, assigns the next available index to the new variable, sets vid to this index, and returns true.
member.returns: true if added successfully, otherwise false

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.IRowVariableModel.GetValue(System.Int32)
member.summary: Get the value associated with the variable index. This is typically used to fetch solver result
member.returns: the variable value

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.IRowVariableModel.SetValue(System.Int32,Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.Rational)
member.summary: Sets the default value for a vid.
member.remarks: The default value for a vid is Indeterminate. An IRowVariableModel can be used to represent not just a model, but also a current state for the models (user and row) variables. The state associates with each vid a current value represented as a Rational. This state may be used as a starting point when solving, and may be updated by a solve attempt. Some solvers may ignore this initial state for rows and even for variables.
member.param: The default value for the variable.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.IRowVariableModel.SetIntegrality(System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Mark a variable as an integer variable
member.param: whether to be an integer variable

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.IRowVariableModel.GetIntegrality(System.Int32)
member.summary: Check if a variable is an integer variable
member.returns: true if this variable is an integer variable. Otherwise false.

member.name: P:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.IRowVariableModel.KeyComparer
member.summary: Used for row or variable key comparison

member.name: P:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.IRowVariableModel.Indices
member.summary: return the variable index collection, inclusive of rows

member.name: P:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.IRowVariableModel.Keys
member.summary: Return the variable and row key collection. Indices are guaranteed to >= 0 and < KeyCount.

member.summary: IGoalModel represents an optimization model with goals.
member.remarks: This interface is inherited by model interfaces such as ILinearModel and INonlinearModel. Goals are identified using integer indexes (vids). Multiple goals can be specified using multiple calls to AddGoal.

member.param: The priority of the goal (smaller values are prioritized first).
Whether to minimize the goal row.
member.returns: An IGoal object representing the goal.

member.param: The IGoal corresponding to the vid.
member.returns: True if this a goal row, otherwise false.

member.name: T:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.INonlinearSolution
member.summary: An INonlinearSolution instance encapsulates the result of attempting to solve an IRowVariableSolver (INonlinearSolver or ITermSolver).
member.remarks: INonlinearSolution contains the following information: The solvers final status, retrievable from Result property, The variable values, indicating the solvers best attempt at an optimal feasible solution. The GetValue method provides this information. Detailed information on which goals were considered and solved to optimality.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.INonlinearSolution.GetValue(System.Int32)
member.summary: Return the value for the variable (or optionally row) with the specified vid.
member.returns: The value of the variable as a double.
member.remarks: This method can always be called with variable vids. Some solvers support row vids as well. The value may be finite, infinite, or indeterminate depending on the solution status.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.INonlinearSolution.GetSolutionValue(System.Int32)
member.summary: Get the objective value of a goal.

member.param: The goal index: 0 <= goal index < SolvedGoalCount.
Whether the goal is minimization goal.

member.name: T:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.INonlinearModel
member.summary: INonlinearModel represents a non-linear optimization model. It has row, variables and goals, and in addition it has callback that define the values and possible the gradients of the rows.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.INonlinearModel.GetActiveVariables(System.Int32)
member.summary: Specify variables that participate in the row.
member.returns: Enumeration of active variables on rowVid
member.exception: Thrown if rowVid is not a legal row id.
member.remarks: In the case of a model which has explicit linear terms (implements ILinearModel), there is no need to specify the linear terms with this call. If no call to SetActiveVariables has been made for the row then this method will return an empty result.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.INonlinearModel.IsActiveVariable(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Indicates whether a variable is active in the specified row.
member.returns: Returns true if variable is active, otherwise false.
member.exception: Thrown if rowVid is not a legal row index, or varVid is not a legal variable index.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.INonlinearModel.SetActiveVariables(System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Set all variables in a row to be active (or inactive).
member.param: If true, all variables become active, if false all variables become inactive.
member.exception: Thrown if rowVid is not a legal row index.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.INonlinearModel.SetActiveVariable(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Sets a variable in the specified row to be active (or inactive).
member.param: If true, the variable becomes active, if false it becomes inactive.
member.exception: Thrown if rowVid is not a legal row index, or varVid is not a legal variable index.

member.name: P:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.INonlinearModel.FunctionEvaluator
member.summary: Function value callback. The callback will be invoked periodically by the solver in order to obtain function values for different variable values.
member.remarks: The callback has several arguments. The first argument is the INonlinearModel being solved. The second is a System.Int32 representing the row (goal or constraint) id to be evaluated. The third is a ValuesByIndex containing the current variable values accessible by id. Next is a System.Boolean that indicates whether this is first evaluator call with the current variable values. The return value is a System.Double which should be the value of the row for the current variable values. This callback must be set before trying to solving the model.

member.name: P:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.INonlinearModel.GradientEvaluator
member.summary: Gradient callback. The callback will be invoked periodically by the solver in order to obtain gradient information for different variable values.
member.remarks: The callback has several arguments. The first argument is the INonlinearModel being solved. The second is a System.Int32 representing the row (goal or constraint) id to be evaluated. The third is a ValuesByIndex containing the current variable values accessible by id. Next is a System.Boolean that indicates whether this is first evaluator call with the current variable values. The last argument is a ValuesByIndex object which should contain the gradient values on return. The callback function should set the values for all variables that were previously declared as active using the SetActiveVariables method.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.ITermModel.AddOperation(Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.TermModelOperation,System.Int32@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Adds an operation row to the model. This row can be turned into a constraint by setting the bounds. Examples of 1-operand operations: identity, negation, not, sin, cos, tan, exp, log, abs Examples of 2-operand operations: plus, minus, times, quotient, pow, max, min, and, or, equality/inequalities Examples of 3-operand operations: if

member.returns: True if a new row was added. False if an existing row was reused.

member.name: T:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.Rational
member.summary:
Non zero finite rational values are represented as a pair (num, den) with den > 0. The numerator and denominator are relatively prime, ie, gcd(num, den) = 1.
Zero is represented as (0, 0) so that default(Rational) == 0. There are 4 other valid values with zero denominator: (1) NegativeInfinity, represented by (-1, 0). (2) PositiveInfinity, represented by (+1, 0). (3) UnsignedInfinity, represented by (+2, 0). (4) Indeterminate, aka NaN, represented by (+3, 0).
Unlike with IEEE double arithmetic, we have 3 representations of inifinity (not 2). Dividing a nonzero value by zero results in an UnsignedInfinity, since 0 is itself unsigned. Dividing a finite value by any of the infinities results in 0.

member.summary: The entering variable index.

member.summary: The state of the variable before entering.

member.name: P:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Solvers.ISimplexPivotInformation.Determinant
member.summary: The determinant of this transformation. This is the "pivot" value, or diagonal entry of the eta matrix. The determinant of the new basis is this value times the determinant of the old basis.

member.name: P:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Solvers.ISimplexPivotInformation.ApproxCost

member.name: T:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.ISecondOrderConicModel
member.summary: Encapsulates a second order conic optimization problem.
member.remarks: Second order conic (SOCP) models are distinguished from linear models by the use of conic constraints. Cones come in two types: quadratic and rotated quadratic.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.ISecondOrderConicModel.AddRow(System.Object,Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.SecondOrderConeType,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Add a reference row for a second order cone. Each cone has one reference row.
member.param: the vid of the reference row

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.ISecondOrderConicModel.SetPrimaryConic(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Specifies a primary variable for a cone.
member.param: The reference row for the cone.
member.remarks: Quadratic cones have one primary variable. SetPrimaryConic must be called twice for rotated quadratic cones because they have two primary variables.

member.name: P:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.ISecondOrderCone.PrimaryVid1
member.summary: The primary conic variable. For a quadratic cone it is x1 where x1 >= || x2 ||, x1 > 0.
member.remarks: -1 means there is no primary conic variable - the cone is empty.

member.name: P:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.ISecondOrderCone.PrimaryVid2
member.summary: The secondary conic variable. For a rotated quadratic cone it is x2 where x1 x2 >= || x3 ||, x1, s2 > 0.
member.remarks: -1 means either the cone is not rotated, or there are fewer than 2 conic vars.

member.name: T:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.SolverRegistrationCollection
member.summary: Plug-in solver registration information.
member.remarks: SolverRegistrationCollection stores information about registered third-party solvers. This information is accessed using the SolverContext.RegisteredSolvers property. A registration entry contains information such as the name of the plug-in assembly and the solver capability and interface it supports. This information is stored in the SolverRegistration class. A single plug-in solver may have multiple SolverRegistration entries, one for each capability supported by the solver. Entries are added to the collection automatically when a configuration file is associated with the application, or by calling the Add method.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.AMD.RemoveSupernodes(System.Int32[],System.Int32[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32[],System.Int32[],System.Int32@)
member.summary: Detect and remove supernodes.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.AMD.Postorder(System.Int32[],System.Int32[])
member.summary: Determine the final AMD ordering based on the assembly tree. The assembly tree is stored in columnStarts and is a tree that consists of all nodes/elements that were chosen during the AMD procedure. Nodes and elements that were absorbed into supernodes are not present in the tree. Therefore we need to add them to the assembly tree before actually performing the postordering. The postordering permutes the ordering in a way that preserves the nonzero structure, but gives better structure to the factor.

Timeout may occur if CheckAbort reports true

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.SymmetricFactorWorkspace.ForwardSolve(Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.Vector,System.Double[])
member.summary:
Solve Lx = y for x
y[0] = y[0] / L[0,0] for i = 1:n-1 y[i] = (y[i] - L[i,0:i-1]*y[0:i-1])/L[i,i]
see Golub & Van Loan, 3.1.1, modified not to overwrite y. A complete solve may be written: x = BackwardSolve(ForwardSolve(y))
member.returns: a new x

members.member:
Solve Ux = y for x, U is upper triangular (== L-transpose)
y[n-1] = y[n-1] / U[n-1,n-1] for i = n-2:0 y[i] = (y[i] - U[i,i+1:n-1]*y[i+1:n-1])/U[i,i]
A complete solve may be written: x = BackSolve(ForwardSolve(z))
see Golub & Van Loan, 3.1.2 y is overwritten with the result space to accumulate Real parts the overwritten y

member.summary: Solve FactoredSymmetricM * x = z for unknown x

member.name: T:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.MinimizeLocalFillWorkspace
member.summary: An inexact minimum local fill ordering algorithm.

member.name: F:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.MinimizeLocalFillWorkspace._diagonalExponents
member.summary: [outerCol]. if not null, influences stable permutation order. A value of -128 indicates a zero diagonal. Other values are capped at -127..127 representing the binary exponent of the diagonal element. A 0 value (default) is thus for a diagonal value in the range 0.5 .. 1.0.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.ILogSource.AddListener(System.Diagnostics.TraceListener,Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.LogIdSet)
member.summary: Adds a listener to the list of listeners. The listener will receive log messages that have the correct mask.
member.remarks: If the listener is already in the list of listeners, the mask is updated. If the mask is empty, the listener is removed from the list of listeners. This is equivalent to calling RemoveListener.
member.returns: True if the listener is added to the list of listeners; false if the listener is already in the list.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.ILogSource.RemoveListener(System.Diagnostics.TraceListener)
member.summary: Removes a listener from the list of listeners.
member.remarks: Removing a listener that has not been added has no effect.

member.summary: This builds the inverse.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.Permutation.ForceMap(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Forces ivSrc to map to ivDst. If ivCur currently maps to ivDst, this is equivalent to Swap(ivSrc, ivCur).

member.summary: This moves item rgv[iv] to rgv[this[iv]].

member.summary: This moves item rgv[this[iv]] to rgv[iv].

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.Permutation.ApplyInvCore``1(``0[],System.Int32[])
member.summary: This moves item rgv[rgivMap[iv]] to rgv[iv]. This assumes rgivMap has the same head list as _rgiv (and _rgivInv). In fact, this is currently only called with rgivMap set to _rgiv or _rgivInv.

member.name: T:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.Decision
member.summary: A group of decision variables for which a solver finds values.
member.remarks: Decisions are output variables determined by a solver. All decisions have a Domain which determine the range of acceptable values. A decision may be single-valued (scalar), or multi-valued (a table). To create a single-valued decision, pass in a zero-length indexSets array. If indexSets has nonzero length, each element represents a set of values over which the decision is indexed. For example, if there are two index sets, then this decision takes two indexes, one from the first set and one from the second set. The total number of decisions is the product of the sizes of all the index sets.

member.name: T:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.Term
member.summary: A term used in a model decision, formula, goal or constraint.
member.remarks: Terms may represent data such as constants, decisions, or parameters. Terms may also represent operations that combine other Term objects, for example arithmetic or logical operations. The Model class has static methods that produce terms for many standard mathematical operations.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.Decision.#ctor(Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.Domain,System.String)
member.summary: Create a new decision. The decision may be a single value (scalar), or multiple values (a table). To create a single-value decision, pass in a zero-length indexSets array. If indexSets has nonzero length, each element of it represents a set of values which this decision is indexed by. For example, if there are two index sets, then this decision takes two indexes, one from the first set and one from the second set. The total number of decisions is the product of the sizes of all the index sets.
member.param: The set of values each element of the decision can take, such as Model.Real
A name for the decision. The name must be unique. If the value is null, a unique name will be generated.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.Decision.#ctor(Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.Domain,System.String,Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.Set[])
member.summary: Create a new decision. The decision may be a single value (scalar), or multiple values (a table). To create a single-value decision, pass in a zero-length indexSets array. If indexSets has nonzero length, each element of it represents a set of values which this decision is indexed by. For example, if there are two index sets, then this decision takes two indexes, one from the first set and one from the second set. The total number of decisions is the product of the sizes of all the index sets.
member.param: The set of values each element of the decision can take, such as Model.Real
A name for the decision. The name must be unique. If the value is null, a unique name will be generated.
The index sets to use. Omit to create a scalar decision.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.Decision.SetBinding``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},System.String)
member.summary:
Binds the decision to data. A decision does not need to be bound to data. If it is, the data must be in the form of a sequence of objects, where each object has properties for the value and index(s) of the data element. The sequence must contain one object for each decision.
The data is written when Context.PropagateDecisions is called.
member.param: A sequence of objects, one for each data element.
The name of the property of each input object which will be assigned the value of the data decisions.
member.exception: A property or field isn't found.
The property or field is not writable.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.Decision.SetBinding``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},System.String,System.String[])
member.summary:
Binds the decision to data. A decision does not need to be bound to data. If it is, the data must be in the form of a sequence of objects, where each object has properties for the value and index(s) of the data element. The sequence must contain one object for each decision.
The data is written when Context.PropagateDecisions is called.
member.param: A sequence of objects, one for each data element.
The name of the property of each input object which will be assigned the value of the data decisions.
The names of the properties of each input object which contain the indexes of the data decisions, one for each index set which was provided when the Decision was created.
member.exception: A property or field isn't found.
The property or field is not writable.

member.name: T:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.RecourseDecision
member.summary: RecourseDecisions are Decisions that are made in response to the realization of a RandomParameter.
member.remarks: Recourse decisions are sometimes called "second-stage" because such decisions can be made only after the randomness is resolved. Each RecourseDecision has an underlying Decision for each second stage problem. Example: the weather may be modeled using a ScenariosParameter. If the weather turns out to be dry, we may not be able to produce enough of a certain crop and may need to purchase it from someone else. In this case, the purchase amount is a recourse decision.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.RecourseDecision.#ctor(Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.Domain,System.String)
member.summary: Create a new non-indexed recourse decision.
member.param: The set of values each element of the decision can take, such as Model.Real
A name for the decision. The name must be unique. If the value is null, a unique name will be generated.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.RecourseDecision.#ctor(Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.Domain,System.String,Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.Set[])
member.summary: Create a new indexed recourse decision. The recourse decision may be a single-valued (scalar), or multi-valued (a table). To create a single-valued decision, pass in a zero-length indexSets array. If indexSets has nonzero length, each element of it represents a set of values which this decision is indexed by. For example, if there are two index sets, then this decision takes two indexes, one from the first set and one from the second set. The total number of decisions is the product of the sizes of all the index sets.
member.param: The set of values each element of the decision can take, such as Model.Real
A name for the decision. The name must be unique. If the value is null, a unique name will be generated.
The index sets to use. Omit to create a scalar decision.

member.summary: A directive for the Compact Quasi Newton (CQN) solver.
member.remarks: The CQN solver is suitable for unconstrainted, unbounded non-linear models with real decisions.

member.summary: Create a new instance.

member.summary: Returns a representation of the directive as a string

member.summary: The solver terminates when the geometrically-weighted average improvement falls below the Tolerance.

member.name: P:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.CompactQuasiNewtonDirective.IterationsToRemember
member.summary: Number of previous iterations to remember for estimate of Hessian (m), (default is 17).
member.remarks: Higher values lead to better approximations to Newton's method, but use more memory, and requires more time to compute direction. The optimal setting of IterationsToRemember is problem specific, depending on such factors as how expensive is function evaluation compared to choosing the direction, how easily approximable is the function's Hessian, etc. A range of 15 to 20 is usually reasonable but if necessary even a value of 2 is better than gradient descent.

member.name: P:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.CompactQuasiNewtonDirective.IterationLimit
member.summary: The maximum number of solver iterations.
member.remarks: If the iteration limit is exceeded, the solver will return CompactQuasiNewtonSolutionQuality.Error. The default is Int32.MaxValue.

members.member:

member.name: T:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.GeometricUnivariateDistribution
member.summary:
A geometric distribution.
The probability distribution is of the number Y = X - 1 of Bernoulli trials failures before the first success, supported on the set { 0, 1, 2, 3, ... }. Note that there is different convention which prefer to define the distribution instead supported on the set {1, 2, 3, ... } as the first successed trial

member.name: T:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.Domain
member.summary: A Domain represents the set of possible values for a Decision or Parameter.
member.remarks: Domains determine the range of acceptable values for a Decision or Parameter. A Domain instance is created by calling a static method on the Domain class. Frequently used domains include Domain.Real and Domain.Integer. The domains of decisions and parameters are considered in determining which solvers may be used to solve a model.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.Domain.IsValidValue(System.Object)
member.summary:
Tests whether a boxed value is a member of this domain. For enumerated domains, tests whether the value is a member of the underlying (numeric) domain, rather than a member of the possible strings.
REVIEW shahark: The data check is done seperatly for the Random Parameters. The value here is the just the IDistributedValue itself and not each scenario (for example when dealing with scenarios) There should be domain type that fits here, then the check can be done
member.returns: True if the value is a member of the domain.

member.summary: Tests whether a number is a member of this domain. For enumerated domains, tests whether the value is a member of the underlying (numeric) domain.

Creates a domain narrowing worker. The domain narrowing worker 'owns' the model while it exists; the model shouldn't be changed. Might implement a check to prevent changes while domain narrowing is ongoing. The model can be released by calling Dispose() explicitly.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.DomainProbingWorker.AddProbedDecision(Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.Decision)
member.summary: Takes a decision and creates a corresponding ProbedDecisionHandle which is used for domain narrowing. The decision must be unindexed.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.DomainProbingWorker.FixProbedDecision(Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.ProbedDecisionHandle,Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.Rational)
member.summary: Marks a UI decision as being fixed to a specific value. If the decision is an enum, the input should be on the underlying numeric range. If called on an already-fixed decision, overwrites the previous fixed value.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.DomainProbingWorker.UnfixProbedDecision(Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.ProbedDecisionHandle)
member.summary: Undoes the result of FixUIDecision so that a decision is once again free to vary.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.DomainProbingWorker.DoProbe(System.Func{System.Boolean},Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.Directive[])
member.summary: Does domain probing. Each time the values of a probed decision changes, or a probed decision gets final values, calls _domainConsumerHook with that ProbedDecisionHandle. Returns when probing is complete.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.DomainProbingWorker.ResetValues
member.summary: Clear the possible values of all probed decisions.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.DomainProbingWorker.ResetDomains
member.summary: Set the domains of all variables in the solver to the base (either the full domain if unfixed, or the fixed value).

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.DomainProbingWorker.CreateTask(Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.ConstraintProgrammingDirective)
member.summary: Bind the data to the model, creates the task and initiates the solver reference

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.DomainProbingWorker.FindWinningDirective(System.Func{System.Boolean},Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.Directive[])
member.summary: Find the winning directive from the given directives and ensure no local search algorithm is used
member.return: A ConstraintProgrammingDirective instance. Either a default one or a winning one. Will never be null.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.DomainProbingWorker.TryAllValues(Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.DomainProbingWorker.ProbedDecisionData,System.Func{System.Boolean})
member.summary: Take a probed decision which isn't fixed and try every value which isn't already known to be good. After doing that, we know that we have found every possible value of that decision for which a feasible solution exists.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.DomainProbingWorker.SetBaseDomainAfterPresolve
member.summary: Set base domains of probed decisions after presolve. Certain values may have been removed from presolve. Need to fire events for these values.
member.remarks: This method is called only when Presolve does not find that the model is infeasible

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.DomainProbingWorker.Presolve(System.Func{System.Boolean})
member.summary: Perform a special round of propagation to eliminate conflicting values from domains of bound decisions

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.DomainProbingWorker.Solve(System.Func{System.Boolean})
member.summary: Solve with the solver domains as currently set, and add the results to the appropriate value sets

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.DomainProbingWorker.RegisterSolutionValues(Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.SolverQuality,Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.SolverContext.TaskSummary)
member.summary: Add all values from a solution to the appropriate value sets

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.RowVariableModel.AddRow(System.Object,System.Int32@)
member.summary: If the model already includes a row referenced by key, this sets vid to the rows index and returns false. Otherwise, if the model already includes a user variable referenced by key, this sets vid to -1 and returns false. Otherwise, this adds a new row associated with key to the model, assigns the next available index to the new row, sets vid to this index, and returns true.
member.returns: true if added successfully, otherwise false

member.summary: Validate if the index is a row index.
member.returns: true if a row otherwise false

member.summary: Get the flag whether is bound is ignored.
member.returns: true if bounds are ignored, otherwise false

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.RowVariableModel.SetBounds(System.Int32,Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.Rational,Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.Rational)
member.summary: Set the bounds for a row. Logically, a vid may have an upper bound of Infinity and/or a lower bound of -Infinity. Specifying any other non-finite value for bounds should be avoided. If a vid has a lower bound that is greater than its upper bound, the model is automatically infeasible, now the ArgumentException is thrown for this case.

member.summary: Set or adjust the lower bound of the variable.

member.summary: Set or adjust the upper bound of the variable.

member.summary: Return the bounds for the variable.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.RowVariableModel.AddVariable(System.Object,System.Int32@)
member.summary: The AddVariable method ensures that a user variable with the given key is in the model. If the model already includes a user variable referenced by key, this sets vid to the variables index and returns false. Otherwise, if the model already includes a row referenced by key, this sets vid to -1 and returns false. Otherwise, this adds a new user variable associated with key to the model, assigns the next available index to the new variable, sets vid to this index, and returns true.
member.returns: true if added successfully, otherwise false

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.RowVariableModel.SetValue(System.Int32,Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.Rational)
member.summary: Set the value for the specified vid. The default value for a vid is Indeterminate. An ILinearModel can be used to represent not just a linear model, but also a current state for the models (user and row) variables. The state associates with each vid a current value, represented as a Rational, and a basis status, represented as a boolean. This state may be used as a starting point when solving, and may be updated by a solve attempt. In particular, invoking the Solve method of the SimplexSolver class updates the values and basis status appropriately. Some other solvers may ignore this initial state for rows and even for variables.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.RowVariableModel.GetValue(System.Int32)
member.summary: Get the value associated with the variable index. This is typically used to fetch solver results.
member.returns: the variable value

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.Model.Sos1(Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.Term)
member.summary:
Creates a special ordered sets (type 1) constraint. The input must be of the form c1 * d1 + c2 * d2 + ... where cN are constants and dN are decisions. None of the constants may be zero, and the same constant may not appear twice.
The SOS1 constraint enforces the property that at most one of the given decisions can be nonzero. The constants should be associated with the problem in some natural way. The ordering of the constants is used by the solver to find a solution more quickly.
member.param: The input term for the Sos1 operation.
member.returns: A Term representing the Sos constraint.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.Model.Sos2(Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.Term)
member.summary:
Creates a special ordered sets reference row. The input must be a constraint of the form x == c1 * d1 + c2 * d2 + ... where cN are constants and dN are decisions. The order of the equality matters. None of the constants may be zero, and the same constant may not appear twice.
The result of this is the equality constraint given, plus additional requirements: the sum of the dN must be 1, at most two of the dN can be nonzero, and any nonzero dN must be adjacent in the list produced by sorting the dN by the corresponding cN.
member.param: The input term for the Sos2 operation.
member.returns: A Term representing the Sos constraint.

member.summary: Expands to either zero or one element for each element of the range, as if the function was called for each element on which the condition is true. The function is only actually called once.
member.param: The Set over which to iterate.
A function transforming element terms in the Set to result Terms.
A function transforming element terms in the Set to boolean Terms. The values function will expand only for elements where the condition function is ture.
member.returns: A Term representing the result.

member.name: T:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.OmlValidator
member.summary:
This class implements methods for checking that an OML model is valid.
"Valid" in this case means that only a restricted set of operators are used, and that if each parameter and decision was assigned a value from the appropriate domain, all the goals and constraints would reduce to simple values (numbers for goals, booleans for constraints).
The validator is conservative, in that it only accepts models where it can prove the above two conditions are true.
Note that in some cases, applying standard reductions to an invalid model can produce a valid model.

member.name: T:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.OmlWriter
member.summary:
A method object for converting a Model to an OML Expression.
This preserves the structure of the model, including parameters and labels of constraints/goals.

member.name: F:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.OmlWriter._cachedTermExpressions
member.summary: A cache of expressions resulting for terms. This cache is not necessary for correctness.

member.name: F:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.OmlWriter._constantSymbols
member.summary: A cache from named constants to symbols. Required to ensure that each parameter has a unique symbol.

member.name: F:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.OmlWriter._decisionSymbols
member.summary: A cache from decisions to symbols. Required to ensure that each decision has a unique symbol.

member.name: F:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.OmlWriter._iterationSymbols
member.summary: A cache mapping iteration terms to symbols. This is required to ensure that each iteration term gets a unique symbol.

member.name: F:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.OmlWriter._parameterSymbols
member.summary: A cache from parameters to symbols. Required to ensure that each parameter has a unique symbol.

member.name: F:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.OmlWriter._randomParameterSymbols
member.summary: A cache from parameters to symbols. Required to ensure that each parameter has a unique symbol.

member.name: F:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.OmlWriter._recourseDecisionSymbols
member.summary: A cache from recourse decisions to symbols. Required to ensure that each decision has a unique symbol.

member.name: F:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.OmlWriter._cachedSets
member.summary: A cache mapping sets to terms. This is necessary so that each set gets only one unique symbol.

member.name: F:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.OmlWriter._randomParameterTypes
member.summary: A mapping from random parameter type to its corresponding expression in OML

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.OmlWriter.Translate(Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.Model)
member.summary: Translate a model into OML. The result is an invocation with Model as its head. The invocation might be empty.

member.summary: Add all SubmodelName -> Model[...] sections.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.OmlWriter.AddSets(Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.Model,System.Collections.Generic.List{Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Rewrite.Expression})
member.summary: Add all Parameters[Sets, ...] sections. Each group of sets sharing a domain are grouped together. Domains are compared with object identity, so sets whose domains are two different calls to Domain.RealRange(...) will be placed in different sections.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.OmlWriter.GetSets(Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.Model)
member.summary: Get all sets from the model. This is similar to Model.ModelSets, but guarantees that the sets are added in a consistent order (given a consistent order of Parameters and Decisions).

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.OmlWriter.AddDecisionSections(Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.Model,System.Collections.Generic.List{Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Rewrite.Expression})
member.summary: Add all Decisions[...] sections to the model. Like AddSets, this groups decisions with the same domain. Indexed decisions are handled appropriately.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.OmlWriter.GetRecourseDecisionDefintion(Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Rewrite.Expression)
member.summary: Wrap the recourse decision name with Recourse invocation

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.OmlWriter.AddParameterSections(Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.Model,System.Collections.Generic.List{Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Rewrite.Expression})
member.summary: Add all Parameters[...] sections to the model. Like AddSets, this groups parameters with the same domain. Indexed parameters are handled appropriately.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.OmlWriter.TranslateScenarios(Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Rewrite.Expression,Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.ScenariosParameter)
member.summary: Gets expression with all the explicit scenarios of the ScenariosParameter e.g. gasDemand= {{0.3, 1900}, {0.4, 2000}, {0.3, 2100} }
A helper function to group something (decisions, parameters, sets) by domains.
member.param: A list of section contents which go into the final model.
A dictionary from domains to lists of section contents.
The domain of the section to find. If it doesn't exist, a new list of expressions is created, and the translation of the domain is added as the first element.
If true, the first element is wrapped in Sets[] when creating a new list of expressions.
member.returns: A list of expressions representing the contents of the correct section. The list can be modified.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.OmlWriter.AddConstraints(Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.Model,System.Collections.Generic.List{Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Rewrite.Expression})
member.summary: Add a Constraints[] section to the model. Only one Constraints[] section is generated. Each constraint is labeled.

member.summary: Add a Goals[] section to the model for each goal. Each goal is labeled.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.OmlWriter.AddNamedConstants(System.Collections.Generic.List{Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Rewrite.Expression})
member.summary: Add all named constants ("Parameters[..., P = constant]") to the model. Named constants go before the other model sections, but are added last because they are discovered while writing the Goals and Constraints sections.

member.name: T:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.RandomParameter
member.summary: A group of terms that take stochastic values.
member.remarks: Random parameters are used to model randomness in input data. Random parameters can be discrete or continuous, and can be used where (non-random) Parameters or constants would normally be used in Constraints. RandomParameter is the base class for a number of commonly used distributions including uniform, normal, and log normal. A special type of random parameter is a ScenariosParameter, where each scenario contains a value and a probability.

member.name: T:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.ScenariosParameter
member.summary: A parameter representing a fixed, finite number of discrete scenarios.
member.remarks: A ScenariosParameter is associated with an underlying set of Scenario objects. Each Scenario defines a possible value for the random parameter along with the probability of the scenario actually occurring. The sum of probabilities over all scenarios equals 1.0.

member.name: T:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.NormalDistributionParameter
member.summary: A normal (Gaussian) distribution parameter.
member.remarks: A normal distribution is a bell-shaped continuous random distribution. The distribution is defined by its mean value and its standard distribution. The distribution is symmetric about the mean value. Normal distributions are sometimes defined using the variance rather than standard deviation - the variance is the square of the standard deviation.

member.name: T:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.GeometricDistributionParameter
member.summary: A random parameter with geometric distribution.
member.remarks: A geometric distribution is a discrete random distribution defined by a success probability parameter. The distribution describes a process where independent Bernoulli trials are taken with the given success probability. The probability distribution is of the number Y = X - 1 of Bernoulli trial failures before the first success, supported on the set { 0, 1, 2, 3, ... }. (Note that this is different from an alternate convention which defines the distribution as the first successful trial supported on the set {1, 2, 3, ... }.)

member.name: T:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.PseudoRandom
member.summary:
Abstract pseudo-random number generator. Use the various Create methods to create instances.
The periods are large (at least 2^19937 - 1) and the generators pass both the DIEHARD and NIST tests.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.PseudoRandom.Create
member.summary: Return the default pseudo-random number generator--a high quality linear algorithm. The same sequence of numbers will be returned for every run of the algorithm. But different instances will typically produce different sequences. REVIEW shahark: i believe the unchecked is unnecessary, as it happens by default

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.PseudoRandom.CreateVerification

The same sequence of numbers will be returned for every run of the algorithm. But different instances will typically produce different sequences.

member.name: T:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.RijndaelPseudoRandom
member.summary:
Pseudo-random number generator based on the Rijndael algorithm. Used for verifing the MersenneTwisterPseudoRandom sequence.
Essentially the idea is to take the output of the MersenneTwisterPseudoRandom and encrypt it with the Rijndael algorithm in code book mode. This gives a nonlinear list of pseudo-random numbers with a very high period and reasonably good efficiency. The algorithm works because Rijndael has good bit dispersion and the input sequence has a good period and bit distribution. The paper below recommends the sequence 0, 1, 2, ... but this has a low period and poor bit distribution.
Algorithm based on Peter Hellekalek and Stefan Wegenkittl, Empirical Evidence Concerning AES ACM Transactions on Modeling and Computer Simulation, Vol. 13, No. 4, October 2003, Pages 322333
Because the Rijndael algorithms block size does not fit evenly into the Mersenne twisters period, the period is large >>2^19937 - 1. The generator passes both the DIEHARD and NIST tests.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.RijndaelPseudoRandom.#ctor(System.UInt32)
member.summary: Create a new sequence of random numbers based on a seed.
member.param: The seed to base the generator on.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.RijndaelPseudoRandom.FillBuffer
member.summary: If necessary fill the buffer with random bytes.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.RijndaelPseudoRandom.NextUInt32
member.summary: Return a uniform pseudo-random number in the range [0,0xffffffff] suitable for simulation work. Note: this number is not cryptographically secure.
member.remarks: The Rijndael algorithm is being used with fixed and easily discoverable keys thus the resulting numbers are not suitable for cryptographic uses.

member.name: T:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.MersenneTwisterPseudoRandom
member.summary:
Pseudo-random number generator based on the Mersenne Twister algorithm.
Makoto Matsumoto and Takuji Nishimura "Mersenne Twister: A 623-Dimensionally Equidistributed Uniform Pseudo-Random Number Generator" ACM Transactions on Modeling and Computer Simulation, Vol. 8, No. 1, January 1998, Pages 330.
The period is large 2^19937 - 1 and the generator passes both the DIEHARD and NIST tests.
member.remarks: The original algorithm used 64 bit arithmetic heavily. Since CLR 64 bit integer arithmetic is slow on x86 architectures, I have converted it to use 32 bit integer arithmetic where possible.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.MersenneTwisterPseudoRandom.#ctor(System.UInt32)
member.summary: Create a new sequence of random numbers based on a seed.
member.param: The seed to base the generator on.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.MersenneTwisterPseudoRandom.BuildSeeds
member.summary: If the current list of seeds is exhausted build a new list.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.MersenneTwisterPseudoRandom.NextUInt32
member.summary: Return a uniform pseudo-random number in the range [0,0xffffffff] suitable for simulation work. Note: this number is not cryptographically secure.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.SolverContext.LoadModel(Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.FileFormat,System.String)
member.summary: Load a model from a file.
member.param: For MPS and OML exact path to the file is needed. For SMPS files, the path represents the core file, or a directory. In the first case the other two files (stoch and time) should be in the same directory as the core file and their prefix should be the same to the core file. The path can be also be to the "time" file or the "stoch" file In the latter case the directory should contain the "core", "stoch" and "time" files with a prefix which is identical to the directory name. Suffixes supported - Core files: .cor, .core. Time files: .tim, .time. Stoch files: .sto, .stoch.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.SolverContext.GetWaitingTimes(Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.Directive[],System.Int64@,System.Int64@)
member.summary: To do this right, we'd need to combine the gate with time limits per thread I think we should create an ordered list of time limits and do a wait with timing and check each of the threads. practically speaking we are limited in the number of threads, so I think linear passing through the thread list determining which one(s) to stop are possible. Instead, we just use the longest time limit. However, timelimits of infinity (-1) are ignored for deciding the longest.

member.name: T:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.SolverQuality
member.summary: solver result

member.name: F:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.SolverQuality.Optimal
member.summary: The result is optimal.

member.name: F:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.SolverQuality.Feasible
member.summary: The model is feasible, but the result found was not proven optimal.

member.name: F:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.SolverQuality.Infeasible
member.summary: The model is infeasible.

member.name: F:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.SolverQuality.Unbounded
member.summary: The model is feasible, but there is no optimal solution because the optimal goal value is infinite.

member.name: F:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.SolverQuality.InfeasibleOrUnbounded
member.summary: The model was proved to have no optimum solution, but the solver was unable to determine whether or not it is feasible.

member.name: F:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.SolverQuality.Unknown
member.summary: The solver was unable to find a solution or prove the model infeasible. This could be because the solver was interrupted, or because the model has no solution but the solver was unable to prove it.

member.name: F:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.SolverQuality.LocalOptimal
member.summary: The solver found a solution which is locally optimal, but may not be globally optimal.

member.name: F:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.SolverQuality.LocalInfeasible
member.summary: The solver found a solution which is locally infeasible, but can not determine if the model is globally infeasible.

member.summary: Create a new instance.

member.summary: Adds an operation row to the model.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.TermModel.AddOperation(Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.TermModelOperation,System.Int32@,System.Int32[])
member.summary: Adds an operation row to the model.
member.remarks: This overload is supported for the following TermModelOperation values: And, Equal, Greater, GreaterEqual, Less, LessEqual, Max, Min, Or, Plus, Times, Unequal.

member.summary: Get the operation for the specified row.

member.summary: Get the operand count for the specified row.
member.returns: The operand count.

member.summary: Get the operands for the specified row.
member.returns: An IEnumerable containing the operand vids.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.TermModel.SetBounds(System.Int32,Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.Rational,Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.Rational)
member.summary: Set the bounds for a vid.
member.remarks: Logically, a vid may have an upper bound of Infinity and/or a lower bound of -Infinity. Specifying any other non-finite values for bounds should be avoided. If a vid has a lower bound that is greater than its upper bound, the model is automatically infeasible, and ArgumentException is thrown.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.TermModel.SetLowerBound(System.Int32,Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.Rational)
member.summary: Set or adjust the lower bound of the vid.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.TermModel.SetUpperBound(System.Int32,Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.Rational)
member.summary: Set or adjust the upper bound of the vid.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.TermModel.SetValue(System.Int32,Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.Rational)
member.summary: Sets the default value for a vid.
member.remarks: The default value for a vid is Indeterminate. An IRowVariableModel can be used to represent not just a model, but also a current state for the models (user and row) variables. The state associates with each vid a current value represented as a Rational. This state may be used as a starting point when solving, and may be updated by a solve attempt. Some solvers may ignore this initial state for rows and even for variables.
member.param: The default value for the variable.

member.name: T:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.SimplifiedTermModelWrapper
member.summary: This class wraps an ITermModel and applies some simplifications as the model is built.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.SimplifiedTermModelWrapper.AddOperation(Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.TermModelOperation,System.Int32@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Adds an operation row to the model. This row can be turned into a constraint by setting the bounds. Examples of 1-operand operations: identity, negation, not, sin, cos, tan, exp, log, abs Examples of 2-operand operations: plus, minus, times, quotient, pow, max, min, and, or, equality/inequalities Examples of 3-operand operations: if
member.param: The vid of the new row, or the vid of an existing row that would have the same value as the new row.
member.returns: True if a new row was added. False if an existing row was reused.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.SimplifiedTermModelWrapper.AddOperation(Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.TermModelOperation,System.Int32@,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Adds an operation row to the model.
member.param: The vid of the new row, or the vid of an existing row with the same value as the new row.
Vid of the first input argument.
Vid of the second input argument.
member.returns: True if a new row was added. False if an existing row was reused.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.SimplifiedTermModelWrapper.AddOperation(Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.TermModelOperation,System.Int32@,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Adds an operation row to the model.
member.param: The vid of the new row, or the vid of an existing row with the same value as the new row.
Vid of the first input argument.
Vid of the second input argument.
Vid of the third input argument.
member.returns: True if a new row was added. False if an existing row was reused.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.SimplifiedTermModelWrapper.AddOperation(Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.TermModelOperation,System.Int32@,System.Int32[])
member.summary: Adds an operation row to the model.
member.param: The vid of the new row, or the vid of an existing row with the same value as the new row.
The vids of the input arguments.
member.returns: True if a new row was added. False if an existing row was reused.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.SimplifiedTermModelWrapper.AddVariable(System.Object,System.Int32@,Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.Rational,Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.Rational,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Adds a variable to the model, with bounds and integrality given at creation time.
member.param: The optional key of the new variable, or null.
The vid of the new variable, or of an existing variable with the same key.
True if the new variable should be restricted to only integer values.
member.returns: True if a new variable was added. False if an existing variable had the same key.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.SimplifiedTermModelWrapper.AddVariable(System.Object,System.Int32@,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.Rational})
member.summary: Adds a variable to the model, with a fixed set of possible values.
member.param: The optional key of the new variable, or null.
The vid of the new variable, or of an existing variable with the same key.
An array of possible values of the new variable. The caller must not modify the array after passing it to this function.
member.returns: True if a new variable was added. False if an existing variable had the same key.

member.summary: Adds a constant to the model. Constants are considered rows.
member.param: The value of the constant to create.
The vid of the new constant, or the vid of an existing constant with the same value.
member.returns: True if a new constant was added. False if an existing constant was reused.

member.summary: Maps the variable index from the key. If not found, KeyNotFoundException will be thrown
member.returns: variable index

member.summary: Try to get the variable index based on the key

member.summary: Map from the variable index to the key. If not found, ArgumentException will be thrown

member.remarks: key might be null

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.SimplifiedTermModelWrapper.AddRow(System.Object,System.Int32@)
member.summary: If the model already includes a row referenced by key, this sets vid to the rows index and returns false. Otherwise, if the model already includes a user variable referenced by key, this sets vid to -1 and returns false. Otherwise, this adds a new row associated with key to the model, assigns the next available index to the new row, sets vid to this index, and returns true.
member.returns: true if added successfully, otherwise false

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.SimplifiedTermModelWrapper.IsRow(System.Int32)
member.summary: Validate if it is a row index and not a variable index.
member.returns: True if a row otherwise false.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.SimplifiedTermModelWrapper.SetIgnoreBounds(System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Adjusts whether the bounds of a vid should be respected or ignored during solving. By default, bounds are respected.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.SimplifiedTermModelWrapper.GetIgnoreBounds(System.Int32)
member.summary: Get the flag whether is bound is ignored.
member.returns: true if bounds are ignored, otherwise false

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.SimplifiedTermModelWrapper.SetBounds(System.Int32,Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.Rational,Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.Rational)
member.summary: Logically, a vid may have an upper bound of Infinity and/or a lower bound of -Infinity. Specifying any other non-finite values for bounds should be avoided. If a vid has a lower bound that is greater than its upper bound, the model is automatically infeasible, now the ArgumentException is thrown for this case.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.SimplifiedTermModelWrapper.SetLowerBound(System.Int32,Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.Rational)
member.summary: set or adjust the lower bound of the variable

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.SimplifiedTermModelWrapper.SetUpperBound(System.Int32,Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.Rational)
member.summary: set or adjust the upper bound of the variable

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.SimplifiedTermModelWrapper.GetBounds(System.Int32,Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.Rational@,Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.Rational@)
member.summary: Return the bounds for the variable

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.SimplifiedTermModelWrapper.AddVariable(System.Object,System.Int32@)
member.summary: The AddVariable method ensures that a user variable with the given key is in the model. If the model already includes a user variable referenced by key, this sets vid to the variables index and returns false. Otherwise, if the model already includes a row referenced by key, this sets vid to -1 and returns false. Otherwise, this adds a new user variable associated with key to the model, assigns the next available index to the new variable, sets vid to this index, and returns true.
member.returns: true if added successfully, otherwise false

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.SimplifiedTermModelWrapper.GetValue(System.Int32)
member.summary: Get the value associated with the variable index. This is typically used to fetch solver result
member.returns: the variable value

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.SimplifiedTermModelWrapper.SetValue(System.Int32,Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.Rational)
member.summary: The default value for a vid is Indeterminate. An IRowVariableModel can be used to represent not just a model, but also a current state for the models (user and row) variables. The state associates with each vid a current value represented as a Rational. This state may be used as a starting point when solving, and may be updated by a solve attempt.

member.name: F:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.TermValueClass.Numeric
member.summary: A numeric value.

member.name: F:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.TermValueClass.Enumerated
member.summary: An enumerated value. Uses a numeric value as an index into a set of strings. Enumerated values can't be used in mathematical operations (except comparisons).

member.name: F:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.TermValueClass.String
member.summary: A string.

member.name: F:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.TermValueClass.Any
member.summary: Either an arbitrary number or an arbitrary string. "Any" values can only be used as an index.

member.name: F:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.TermValueClass.Table
member.summary: A multidimensional parameter or decision. Table values can only be used by indexing into them.

member.name: F:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.TermValueClass.Submodel
member.summary: An instance of a submodel

member.name: F:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.TermValueClass.Distribution
member.summary: A random distribution

member.name: F:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.TermStructure.None
member.summary: No flags

member.name: F:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.TermStructure.Constant
member.summary: Constant after all parameters and iteration terms are fixed

member.name: F:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.TermStructure.Linear
member.summary: Linear in decisions (e.g. "x + 2") A term with this flag is valid as a goal in linear or quadratic models, and (if Boolean) as a constraint in linear or quadratic models.

member.name: F:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.TermStructure.Quadratic
member.summary: Quadratic in decisions (e.g. "x * y + 2") A term with this flag is valid as a goal in quadratic models.

member.name: F:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.TermStructure.LinearInequality
member.summary: Linear inequality (e.g. "x + 2 == 5") A term with this flag is valid as the parameter of an SOS2 constraint.

member.name: F:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.TermStructure.LinearConstraint
member.summary: AND of linear inequalities and/or Boolean constants (e.g. "(x + 2 == 5) & (x + y <= 10)") A term with this flag is valid as a constraint in linear or quadratic models.

member.name: F:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.TermStructure.Integer
member.summary: Uses only integer operations and constants, including all descendants A term with this flag is valid as a goal or constraint in CP models.

member.name: F:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.TermStructure.Multivalue
member.summary: Foreach

member.name: F:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.TermStructure.Sos1
member.summary: Sos1

member.name: F:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.TermStructure.Sos2
member.summary: Sos2

member.name: F:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.TermStructure.Differentiable
member.summary: Differentiable function A term with this flag is valid as a goal in differentiable nonlinear models, and (if Boolean) as a constraint in the same.

member.name: F:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.TermStructure.DifferentiableConstraint
member.summary: AND of differentiable functions and/or Boolean constants A term with this flag is valid as a constraint in differentiable nonlinear models.

member.name: T:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.NamedConstantTerm
member.summary:
A NamedConstantTerm represents a named constant ("Parameters[..., P = constant]" in OML), or a simple function of one or more inputs.
It can be indexed just like a Parameter.
It is possible that the value of a NamedConstantTerm could depend on the value of a Parameter or another NamedConstantTerm. Ensuring that there are no loops is the job of the OML importer.

member.summary: This represents a sum of products by as a row of a sparse matrix.

member.summary: A linear model whose coefficient matrix is used to find the coefficients of the sum

member.summary: A mapping from variable vids to Terms representing the variables

member.name: F:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.RowTerm._vid
member.summary: The vid of the row this term corresponds to

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.RowTerm.TryEvaluateConstantValue(Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Common.Rational@,Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.Term.EvaluationContext)
member.summary: This is a stub method which always returns false. The variables will generally be decisions, so a RowTerm almost always can't be evaluated.

member.name: T:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.SumTermBuilder
member.summary: A SumTermBuilder is used to build Sum terms efficiently.
member.remarks: This class represents a list of operand terms that will be combined into a Sum term. The resulting Sum term can be used in goals or constraints. This class is useful when the number of terms in the sum is unknown at compilation time (otherwise the operands may be passed as an array to Model.Sum). Individual terms are added to SumTermBuilder using the Add method. The ToTerm method returns a Sum term with the previously added terms as operands. The Clear method is convenient when the same SumTermBuilder is used repeatedly to create Sum terms.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.SumTermBuilder.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a new instance with the specified initial capacity.
member.param: The initial capacity of the SumTermBuilder.
member.remarks: If the number of terms exceeds the capacity the SumTermBuilder will be resized appropriately.

member.summary: Clears the SumTermBuilder.

member.summary: Add a new Term.
member.param: A term to add to the SumTermBuilder.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Services.SumTermBuilder.ToTerm
member.summary: Returns a Term object that represents the Sum of the previously added operand terms.
member.returns: A Sum term.

member.name: P:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Solvers.CspTerm.Key
member.summary: All Variable Terms are created with a key object that serves as their identifier. Variable keys will be added to a Dictionary and must be non-null and unique. A Function Term by default has no key. You can assign a key if you wish. The Key is then added to the Dictionary and will appear in the Solution. Attempting to change an existing key will cause an InvalidOperationException.

member.summary: Is this Term tied to a Boolean Domain?

member.name: P:Microsoft.SolverFoundation.Solvers.CspTerm.Inputs
